data.title: Uncaught Error: ENOSPC: no space left on device, write
data.body:
[Enter steps to reproduce:]

1. ...
2. ...

**Atom**: 1.16.0 x64
**Electron**: 1.3.13
**OS**: Ubuntu 16.04.2
**Thrown From**: Atom Core


### Stack Trace

Uncaught Error: ENOSPC: no space left on device, write

```
At fs.js:786

Error: ENOSPC: no space left on device, write
    at Error (native)
    at Object.fs.writeSync (fs.js:786:20)
```

data.title: Add config schema for version pinned packages
data.body:
### Description of the Change

Add configuration schema for version pinned packages. See atom/settings-view#950.

### Alternate Designs

See atom/settings-view#950.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

This is where the configuration schema for `core` settings are defined.

### Benefits

See atom/settings-view#950

### Possible Drawbacks

See atom/settings-view#950

### Applicable Issues

* atom/settings-view#950

data.title: Show stdout in addition to stderr in script/test
data.body: Some test runners output on stdout instead of stderr. This changes `script/test` so that if tests fail, output from stdout will also be shown.

data.title: Update autocomplete-html, autocomplete-css
data.body:
### Requirements

* Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion.
* All new code requires tests to ensure against regressions

### Description of the Change

autocomplete-html has been almost completely rewritten and now features autocomplete descriptions and a smarter autocomplete.  Its completions list has also been updated for the first time in two years.

autocomplete-css just has some minor completion updates.

### Alternate Designs

None.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

Already in core.

### Benefits

* autocomplete-html
  * Descriptions when autocompleting
  * More autocompletions for ambiguous attribute names and boolean properties
  * Smarter autocompletion, especially for attribute flags
* autocomplete-css
  * More completions

### Possible Drawbacks

@Ben3eeE and I have done some pretty thorough regression testing with the new autocomplete-html, so I don't think there'll be any.

### Applicable Issues

None.

data.title: No search results from directories with commas
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

If a directory has commas in a folder name somewhere in the path, you get 0 search results. This seems similar to #8225.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a directory path with commas in one of the folder names.
2. Add files to the folder or one of the subfolders.
3. Perform a search in Find In Project.

**Expected behavior:** 1 or more search results

**Actual behavior:** 0 search results

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

1.16.0

### Additional Information

I confirmed it is because of commas by renaming the folder, changing the commas to underscores. I immediately got search results. The folder path does have periods in it as well.

data.title: Pane shouldn't steal focus from its children
data.body:
This was removed in #14175 in order to solve #14173 (editors not being
focused when clicking tabs). However, it means that the pane steals
focus from its children. The solution is to add the guard back and to
solve #14173 in another way: by delaying the activation of the item
(see atom/tabs#439).

data.title: TextEditor::getPath() can return incorrect case on case-insensitive filesystems
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

If you are on a case-insensitive file system such as Windows or OS X and Atom is opened from the CLI using a path that doesn't match the case of the folder/file in question, the file opens but Atom reports the wrong case.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Have a directory and file with differing cases on a case in-sensitive filesystem.
    * For example: `C:\Temp\CapDir\CapFile.txt` on Windows.
2. Open Atom using the wrong case for the directory.
    * For example: `atom C:\temp\capdir`
3. Open the file in the directory
4. Run `atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor().getPath()` from the Developer Tools and note the incorrect case on the path.

**Expected behavior:**

Running the above command should output `C:\Temp\CapDir\CapFile.txt` regardless of what command was used to launch Atom.

**Actual behavior:**

Any part of the path that was manually specified is taken as verbatim and not corrected to reflect the actual case on the file system. The above steps for example show `C:\temp\capdir\CapFile.txt` as the path to the file.

This causes problems with packages that rely on the correct path, including the case, to be returned such as linters that check for cross platform case issues on case-insensitive filesystems where it would normally not show for the user.

**Reproduces how often:**

100% of the time.

### Versions

Tested locally on Windows 10 x64:
Atom    : 1.17.0-beta5
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

Note that this investigation initially started from a user on macOS Sierra 10.12.3 (16D32) in https://github.com/benmosher/eslint-plugin-import/issues/831.

### Additional Information

Any part of the path that _isn't_ manually specified is handled correctly, for example if the CLI is in `C:\Temp` and Atom is called with `atom capdir` then the resulting path is `C:\Temp\capdir\CapFile.txt`.

Related to https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/8221.

Tagging @lee-dohm as requested.

data.title: [Linux] Dragging a file or folder into Atom does not work
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Description

Dragging a file or directory from a GVFS share does not open it in atom

### Steps to Reproduce

- Open Nautilus.
- Connect to a remote server through the location bar.
- Drag a folder into Atom.

**Expected behavior:**

Atom should open the folder or file, just like it does with local files and folders.

**Actual behavior:**

Atom does nothing.

**Reproduces how often:** 

Every time.

### Versions

1.16.0 and previous

### Additional Information

This Bug goes back to electron / chromium which does not handle the document drop event correctly. I have created an issue with a detailed bug description there. Unfortunately it did not get much attention yet.

See: https://github.com/electron/electron/issues/9319

data.title: Atom 64-bit and grammar rule crashing Windows 10 machine
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

A combination of Atom 64-bit on Windows and the Atom-Silverstripe language plugin causes memory usage in Atom to rocket up at a huge rate before eventually crashing the whole OS.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Intall https://atom.io/packages/atom-silverstripe
2. Enter in a $ symbol

**Expected behavior:** Syntax in the format `$xx` is highlighted

**Actual behavior:** Editor freezes, and memory usage increases dramatically before crashing entire OS (video freeze, audio buffer looping)

**Reproduces how often:** Always

### Versions

Atom 1.16.0 x64 running on Windows 10. 

Originally I noticed this on my own Windows 10 box, but have just reproduced using VirtualBox and an official Microsoft machine. Edge on Win10 (x64) Stable (14.14393). Just fresh Atom installation and this package.

### Additional Information

The line which causes issues is in a .cson grammar file.

` 'match': '\\$(\\.?[a-zA-Z0-9]*(\\([a-zA-Z0-9\'\, ]*\\))*)*'`

I have also reported on the package repo: https://github.com/gorriecoe/atom-silverstripe/issues/7

I could not reproduce on Windows 7 with 32-bit Atom or MacOS.

data.title: keymap handles case inconistently
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

The behavior of the keymap and how it handles letter case is inconsistent. Setting a keykinding to the following values responds when the listed keys are pressed:

- `cmd-shift-P`: cmd-shift-p
- `cmd-P`: cmd-shift-p
- `cmd-shift-p`: cmd-shift-p

When a capital letter is listed in the keymap, `shift` must be pressed to use that command, meaning that all commands `x-shift-p`, `x-shift-P`, and `x-P` are effectively the same. This is an inconsistency because listing a capital letter forces an implied `shift` key to be used, while using a lowercase letter and listing an explicit `shift` key is fine.

Thus:

- `cmd-shift-p == cmd-shift-P`
- `cmd-p != cmd-P`
- `cmd-shift-p == cmd-P`

### Steps to Reproduce

1. In `keymap.cson`, add the lines:

```
'atom-workspace atom-pane':
  # 'cmd-shift-P': 'pane:decrease-size'
  # 'cmd-shift-p': 'pane:decrease-size'
  # 'cmd-P': 'pane:decrease-size'
  # 'cmd-p': 'pane:decrease-size'
```
2. Uncomment each line individually and try pressing the combinations:

- `command, shift, p`
- `command, p`

to see how Atom responds to each.

**Expected behavior:**

- The pane decreases when either of the lines `cmd-shift-P` or `cmd-shift-p` are uncommented and `command, shift, p` are pressed.
- The pane decreases when either of the lines `cmd-P` or `cmd-p` are uncommented and `command, p` are pressed.

**Actual behavior:**

- The pane decreases when any of the lines `cmd-shift-P`, `cmd-shift-p`, `cmd-P` are uncommented and `command, shift, p` are pressed.
- The pane decreases when the line `cmd-p` is uncommented and `command, p` are pressed.

**Reproduces how often:** Consistently according to this pattern.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

### Additional Information

n/a

data.title: How can I open a file in the same tab using cmd+p?
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [ X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Currently, every time I use cmd+p to open a file in Atom, it creates a new tab which leads to tab overload.

I am looking for a way to open a file using cmd+p and have it replace the file I am currently viewing.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open directory in atom with at least 2 files
2. Hit Cmd+P, start typing a filename and click on a file
3. Hit Cmd+P again, start typing a new filename and click on that file

**Expected behavior:** 2nd file replaces the first file so I have only ONE tab open

**Actual behavior:** 2nd file opens in a new tab so now I have TWO tabs open

**Reproduces how often:** [100%

### Versions
Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information

The command is working as expected, but I would think there was some command to have it open in the same tab instead of opening a new tab.

data.title: Research project on OSS motivation - would appreciate help for my master thesis
data.body:
**Dear OSS developer,**

I am a student at the Technical University Munich and I am currently collecting data for my master thesis to understand the motivations of OSS developer. I am interested in finding out what encourages you to give others feedback, to ask questions to the community, or even to produce high-quality software. I'd be really happy if you share your experiences with me and participate in my little survey. It will take you less than 10 minutes. You can find it under the following link: https://www.soscisurvey.de/OSS/?r=H

To say thank you, I will raffle three Amazon gift cards. All information will be treated strictly confidentially and anonymously. If you have any questions or comments, please feel free to contact me (corinna.schmidt@tum.de).

Many thanks in advance and all the best,

Corinna

data.title: Speed up parsing the snapshot source map
data.body:
When calling remote functions or emitting deprecation warnings respectively Electron and Grim create a fake `Error` object to retrieve the stack trace of the current call site.

When doing this for the first time, if the call site was located inside a snapshotted file, previously we would parse the source map for the snapshot and translate the position of each call in the stack trace. However, since the snapshot source map is quite big, we were observing major slowdowns when parsing it for the first time.

With this commit we will parse the snapshot source map while generating the snapshot, which will allow to not pay for it during runtime.

🍐'd with @BinaryMuse.

data.title: TitleBar (MacOS) - custom titlebar doesn't implement path or document proxy
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

New custom MacOS TitleBar does not implement support for standard path popup or drag-n-drop document proxy, as per standard titlebars.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Switch to custom title bar on macos and restart
2. open a document
3. cmd-click in document title in titlebar. A path pop up should appear, but doesn't.
4. drag the document icon, a document proxy should appear for drag and drop, but doesn't.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

I expect the path popup to appear, as it does in default mode, and I expect the document proxy to appear, as it does in default mode.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Neither appear. This is perhaps refered to by "Custom" will affect functionality, but as nice as it is, this is a bridge to far, i'm just wondering if the authors are unaware of this default behaviour.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

Every time.

### Versions

1.16.0 x64 for Mac OS X.

### Additional Information

data.title: option to always retain unsaved buffers no matter what
data.body:
__Problem:__

Currently, unsaved buffers (by that I mean new, unsaved, unnamed buffers with notes etc.) are somewhat loosely associated with atom project.

When you open a new project in a new window, the unsaved buffers are not opened/transferred to that window (whether it's a good thing is subjective). When you close that project (window), those unsaved buffers are (AFAIK) irreversibly lost.

I'm not sure how the unsaved buffers are retained between atom sessions, but if you happen to close the project as stated above, and then do `File → Reopen project`, the unsaved buffers created within that project __are not restored__.

I can't express how many times I've lost work due to atom not re-opening active project (even though it's been mostly fixed [there's so many related issues that I don't keep track] it happens to me every other week or so), thus losing unsaved buffers. I've since learned to keep my most important code-snippets-to-be-processed-later in a saved buffer, but I'm pretty lazy so I forget to do that all the time. And you know, it always happens that the atom loses state right when I put some important stuff in there :).

__Proposal:__

Either one would be fine:

- Add an option to always retain unsaved buffers no matter what, and don't associate them with a project
- Keep them associated with a project, but restore them when doing `File → Reopen project` (or when reopening project via other means)
- Keep easily accessible backup (plaintext) of the unsaved buffers that's not removed under any circumstances (unless either user manually closes that buffer, or saves it) -- or at least have some way to restore unsaved buffers that's not been reopened for some reason.
